derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English: from Latin imprecatio(n-), from imprecari 'invoke (evil'), from in- 'towards' + precari 'pray'

entry.def: An imprecation is something rude, angry, or hostile that is said to or about someone.

means.word_mean: 1. the act of calling down a curse that invokes evil (and usually serves as an insult);

sentences.sentence: "he suffered the imprecations of the mob"

auth_sentence.content: He seemed to have some imprecation caught in his throat and which produced a kind of angry hiccup as he glared up at Blondy.
